On examination, P-90/min, BP-110/76mmHg, temperature 99F, saturation normal, RR-15/min, pallor present. PV examination shows bleed+, cervix dilated 3cm. USG advised. The causes of this condition could be all except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterine fibroid The clinical case is spontaneous miscarriage in the first trimester of pregnancy . Uterine fibroid is a common cause of miscarriage in second-trimester pregnancy. (2) Maternal medical illness. (3) Unexplained.

questions.text: A 26-Yrar-old G2P1 with 18 weeks of gestation presents with a history of pain abdomen and brown discharge pv for five days. No history of trauma. She has no comorbidities. She had a normal vaginal delivery 1yr ago. On examination, P-90/min, BP-126/84mmHg, RR-14/min, afebrile, saturation normal, pallor present. On Abdominal examination, tenderness is present. PV and per speculum examination show brownish discharge, cervix firm. USG shows absent fetal cardiac activity dead fetus. The products of conception were removed, and a dead, macerated fetus with bits of the pale, thin placenta was seen. The diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Missed miscarriage The given case scenario is that of a missed abortion. The clinical history mentions brownish vaginal discharge, a firm cervix on examination, and a dead fetus on us. The presence of macerated fetus shows the death of the fetus would have occurred a few days ago. When the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period, it is called missed miscarriage or early fetal demise. CLINICAL FEATURES: The patient usually presents with features of threatened miscarriage followed by: (1) Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge. (2) Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms.(3) Retrogression of breast changes. (4) Cessation of uterine growth, which in fact, becomes smaller in size. (5) Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound even with Doppler ultrasound if it had been audible before. (6) Cervix feels firm. (7) Immunological test for pregnancy becomes negative. (8) Real-time ultrasonography reveals an empty sac early in the pregnancy or the absence of fetal cardiac motion and fetal movements.

The diagnosis of this patient is as follows:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inevitable miscarriage The given clinical scenario is an Inevitable miscarriage in a primigravida. DEFINITION: It is the clinical type of abortion where the changes have progressed to a state from which continuation of pregnancy is impossible. CLINICAL FEATURES: The patient, having the features of threatened miscarriage, develops the following manifestations: ( 1) Increased vaginal bleeding. (2) Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky. (3) Internal examination reveals dilated internal os of the cervix through which the products of conception are felt. Occasionally, the features may develop quickly without prior clinical evidence of threatened miscarriage. In the second trimester, however, it may start with a rupture of the membranes or intermittent lower abdominal pain (mini labor).

questions.text: A 28-Year-old female, primigravida, 18 weeks of gestation, presents with a history of pain abdomen, fever, and burning micturition for four days. She is a case of type I DM on treatment. On examination, P-110/min, BP-116/72mmHg, RR-22/min, temperature- 104F, saturation- 96 Percent, pallor present, B/L pedal edema upto ankle seen. Abdominal examination shows the presence of tenderness. PV examination shows the presence of purulent vaginal discharge mixed with blood. Samples for CBC, Blood grouping, CRP, ESR, urine analysis, coagulation profile, and S.Electrolytes were sent. Samples for blood and vaginal swab culture were also sent. USG showed retained products of conception, collection of free fluid in the peritoneal cavity, and a pouch of Douglas. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Septic abortion The clinical scenario points toward Septic abortion in a primigravida with 18 weeks of gestation. DEFINITION: Any abortion associated with clinical evidence of infection of the uterus and its contents is called septic abortion. Although clinical criteria vary, abortion is usually considered septic when there is: (1) a rise of temperature of at least 100.4°F (38°C) for 24 hours or more, (2) offensive or purulent vaginal discharge, and (3) other evidence of pelvic infection such as lower abdominal pain and tenderness. INVESTIGATIONS: Routine investigations include: (1) Cervical or high vaginal swab is taken before internal examination for—(a) culture in aerobic and anaerobic media to find out the dominant microorganisms, (b) sensitivity of the microorganisms to antibiotics and (c) smear for Gram stain. Gram-negative organisms are—E. coli, Pseudomonas, Bacteroides, etc. Gram-positive organisms are—Staphylococci, anaerobic Streptococci, group A beta-hemolytic, Streptococci, MRSA, Cl. welchii, Cl. tetani, etc. (2) Blood for hemoglobin estimation, total and differential count of white cells, ABO and Rh grouping. (3) Urine analysis, including culture.

questions.text: A 32-Year-old G3A2 with 11 weeks of gestation presents with a history of bleeding pv and pain abdomen. She has had two abortions; the first was an induced abortion 4yrs ago due to the failure of a contraceptive, and the second was a spontaneous abortion in the first trimester. She has no comorbidities. Her first trimester USG was typical. On examination, P -92/min, BP - 124/78mmHg, RR - 14/min, afebrile, saturation normal, pallor present. Abdominal examination shows tenderness. PV examination shows bleed, contents of conception-like membranes, and part of fetus-like structures. Os is patulous. Expelled mass is incomplete. There is varying bleeding, and the uterus is small in size. The diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Incomplete miscarriage The clinical scenario points towards an incomplete miscarriage. DEFINITION: When the entire products of conception are not expelled. Instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity, called an incomplete miscarriage. This is the commonest type met amongst women hospitalized for miscarriage complications. CLINICAL FEATURES: History of expulsing a fleshy mass per vaginam followed by: (1) Continuation of pain in the lower abdomen. (2) Persistence of vaginal bleeding. (3) Internal examination reveals—(a) uterus smaller than the period of amenorrhea, (b) patulous cervical os often admitting tip of the finger, and (c) varying amount of bleeding. (4) on examination, the expelled mass is found incomplete. (5) Ultrasonography—reveals echogenic material (products of conception) within the cavity.

questions.text: Early fetal death is the death of a fetus at?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

< 20 weeks Fetal death means death before complete expulsion or extraction from the mother of a product of human conception irrespective of the duration of pregnancy and which is not an induced termination of pregnancy. The death is indicated by the fact that after such expulsion or extraction, the fetus does not breathe or show any other evidence of life, such as the beating of the heart, pulsation of the umbilical cord, or definite movement of voluntary muscles. Fetal mortality is divided into three periods: Early, or < 20 completed weeks; intermediate, 20–27 weeks; and late, 28 weeks or more. The fetal death rate after 28 weeks has declined since 1990, whereas deaths from 20 to 27 weeks remain unchanged.

Highyeild:

Early fetal demise: Those early pregnancy losses in which fetal development is observed by ultrasound and fetal tissue is found on the histologic examination.

Extraedge:

Blighted ova: Those early pregnancy losses in which fetal development is not observed with ultrasound (so that only a gestational sac is present with or without a yolk sac) and fetal tissue is absent on histologic examination of the products of conception. The difference between these two types of abortion is of fundamental importance. The lack of development of fetal structures defines a subset of abortions of genetic origin. In contrast, the early interruption of fetal life is a complex phenomenon with multiple etiologies. Therefore, the patients with blighted ova do not require extensive workup, whereas patients who have aborted cytogenetically normal fetuses need an extensive search for nongenetic factors responsible for the pregnancy loss

questions.text: Intrauterine death at 36 weeks. Treatment is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wait for spontaneous expulsion In 80% of cases of IUD, spontaneous expulsion occurs in 2 weeks. If spontaneous expulsion fails to occur within two weeks, intervention should be done.

Highyeild:

Indications for interference: a.Psychological upset of the patient. b. Manifestations of uterine infections. c. Falling fibrinogen level (fibrinogen estimation should be done weekly in case of IUD). d. The tendency of prolongation of pregnancy beyond two weeks. But this type of expectant management, i.e., awaiting spontaneous expulsion, is no longer done. Nowadays, the usual practice is to induce labor as soon as fetal death is diagnosed because most women have a natural disinclination to carry a dead fetus within them.
